posts.name: Elliot Scher
posts.cooked:
Kraken X60s have their screw holes for the CAN ring terminals recessed down from the power ones:

image 918×1075 103 KB

image 918×1075 103 KB

image 918×1075 103 KB

The Kraken X60 adapter boards have these metal extrusions that make contact with the motor when the bolt is screwed in:

Screenshot 2024-08-19 150148 1242×693 159 KB

Screenshot 2024-08-19 150148 1242×693 159 KB

Screenshot 2024-08-19 150148 1242×693 159 KB

I’ve never seen this on a PCB before (admittedly I’m a complete novice when it comes to PCB design ) but I’m curious if this is common practice and where I can learn more about it.

Thanks!!

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
Well you have to make the level change to make contact with the CAN connections when this board is inverted and installed somehow!

In seriousness tho: I have seen this done to elevate electrical connections (typically ring terminals), outside of a case, or to another internal PCB.

I believe if you dig into the Kraken electronics on the motor you might even find some for bringing the CAN or POWER connections to the outside for you to make connection with…

link_counts.title: Announcing Kraken X60 powered by Talon FX!

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
Those look like press fit unthreaded spacers.  There are also threaded ones.  They are commonly used on sheet metal.  In a PCB you can also solder them in, but that may be a bit of a challenge due to thermal mass.  Plus, you need them to stay put while you heat and/or sluice solder across them on the wave.  There’s also a huge range of non-conductive ones to play with.  Even dissolvable spacers!

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked:
Gandagorn:

but I’m curious if this is common practice

I have never really paid attention, but I think it is pretty common were the PCB has to fit the reality of having to connect to things not all on the same plane.
